metadata.title: Bromamine-T mediated aziridination of olefins with a new polymer supported Manganese(II) complex as catalyst
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Scheme 1 Table 1 Elemental analysis at different stages of catalyst preparation Polymer 1 Polymer 2 Polymer 3 %C %H %Cl %C %H %N %Cl %C %H %N %Cl 72.95 5.93 17.50 54.27 4.85 3.45 11.18 61.76 5.69 2.98 10.47 Table 2 Catalytic aziridination of olefins aIsolated yield. The aziridines were characterized by usual spectral analyses. Bromamine-T mediated aziridination of olefins with a new polymer supported Manganese(II) complex as catalyst Dedicated to Dr. T. Ravindranathan on the occasion of his 60th birthday R. Vyas a B.M. Chanda a * A.A. Belhekar b D.R. Patel c R.N. Ram c A.V. Bedekar a a Division of Organic Chemistry: Technology, National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411 008, India b Catalysis Division, National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411 008, India c Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, M.S. University of Baroda, Baroda 390 002, India * Corresponding author. Fax: +91-20-589-3614 Chloromethylated styrene-divinyl benzene of 8% cross-link was functionalized using o-phenylene diamine and finally it was treated with Mn(II) for the formation of metal complex on the surface. The metal content was estimated using atomic absorption spectroscopy. The thermal stability of the catalyst was seen by the use of DTA-TG analyses and the catalyst was found to be stable up to ~125°C. The modern spectroscopic methods such as FT-IR, ESR were used in order to confirm the probable structure of the catalyst. The catalytic activity of this supported Mn(II)-complex was investigated for aziridination of olefins with bromamine-T as the source of nitrogen. The catalyst was found to be effective in this reaction and could be reused with no substantial loss of activity for up to three cycles. Keywords Bromamine-T Olefin Manganese (II) 1 Introduction Polymer-supported metal complexes have found an important place in synthetic organic chemistry exhibiting well documented advantages over the homogeneous systems [1,2]. This type of anchored catalysts have been studied by many researchers to compare the behavior of transition metal catalysts in homogeneous and heterogeneous states, due to higher catalytic activity exhibited by these anchored catalysts under mild reaction parameters [3–6]. Some reports have been published from our group on the immobilization of various metal complexes on organic polymer [7–10] with their applications as catalysts. Aziridines, belonging to the smallest group of heterocycles, is an important class of compounds [11–13] and is especially useful as intermediates for functional group modifications. Synthesis of aziridines is therefore a subject of much research over the last few years. The most atom efficient method of preparation of aziridines lies in the direct aziridination of olefins with suitable nitrenes [14–18]. In our preliminary communication, we have demonstrated [19] the use of bromamine-T, 1 (TsNNaBr) as a superior source of nitrogen in the copper catalyzed aziridination of different olefins. The present study deals with the preparation of chelated manganese metal complex on a polymer support and investigations of its catalytic behaviour in the aziridination of olefins with bromamine-T. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and equipment Acetone, dioxane, methanol, THF were purified according to reported procedures [20]. Acetonitrile was dried on CaH2 and distilled before use. Analytical grade MnCl2·4H2O was used as such. Chloromethylated polystyrene divinylbenzene (PS-DVB) of 8% cross-linked (chlorine content 17.5%) was obtained as gift sample from Ion Exchange (India), Mumbai. The olefins for aziridination reactions were obtained from commercial sources and distilled before the experiments. Bromamine-T was prepared from commercial chloramine-T following the literature procedure [21]. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Coleman analyzer unit. Infra red spectra were recorded in Nujol as well as KBr matrix on Shimadzu 8300 FTIR spectrometer. DTA-TG analysis was recorded on TG-DTA 32 (Seiko, Japan) and ESR in granular form on ESR, Bruker EMX machine. Atomic absorption results were obtained on Varian Atomic Absorption spectrometer. Proton NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker AC-200 machine in CDCl3 with TMS as internal standard. 2.2 Synthesis of the catalyst 2.2.1 Introduction of o-phenylene diamine on the polymer matrix Chloromethylated PS-DVB of 8% cross link was washed with water, water–ethanol mixture (1:1) and finally with ethanol. Any adsorbed material was removed by extracting the polymer in a soxhlet using ethanol–benzene mixture for 10 h. Chlorine content of the polymer beads was estimated using standard method [22] and found to be 17.5%. The chloromethylated PS-DVB was kept in contact with NaI in acetone–dioxane mixture for 4 days. It was purified by soxhlet extraction using acetone as solvent and dried at 60–70°C for 8 h. The polymer beads thus processed were refluxed with o-phenylene diamine in THF (2%) for 2 days and finally it was filtered and washed with THF [23]. The loading of o-phenylene diamine on the polymer (2) was confirmed by the presence of N, which was found to be 3.32%. 2.2.2 Attachment of metal ion on to the polymer anchored ligand In a round bottom flask, 10.0 g of polymer anchored diamine 2 was taken in ethanol (60 ml) and left for about 30 min. To this mixture, ethanolic solution of MnCl2·4H2O (0.25%; 100 ml) was added via an addition funnel over 30 min. The reaction was continued for 7 days at ambient temperature after which the beads of polymer 3 acquired light pink color indicating the formation of metal complex on the surface of the polymeric material. In order to estimate the metal content 99 mg of the catalyst 3 was treated with 1:1 HCl for three times for the total extraction of the metal ions and determined by the atomic absorption spectroscopy. The quantity of Mn present was found to be 2.73×10−2% [23]. 2.3 Aziridination of olefins 2.3.1 A typical procedure for the aziridinatoion of olefin 2.3.1.1 N-p-toluenesulfonyl-2-phenylaziridine A round bottom two neck flask (25 ml cap.) was charged with freshly distilled styrene (0.10 ml; 2.0 mmol), bromamine-T (0.10 g; 0.4 mmol), and Mn-catalyst 3 (0.10 g) along with activated powdered molecular sieves (0.05 g). Dry acetonitrile (5 ml) was added and reaction mixture stirred for 15 h at ambient temperature under the Ar atmosphere. The catalyst was filtered off and washed with dichloromethane and product purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10% EtOAc in light petroleum ether) to afford N-p-toluenesulfonyl-2-phenylaziridine (46.0 mg; 42.0%). The structure was confirmed by proton NMR and mass spectroscopy. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst Elemental analyses at the different stages of preparation of catalyst are given in Table 1 . Elemental analysis and metal estimation of the catalyst indicate a low level of anchoring of the metal ion on to the aminated polymer. Similar observations were made by us while loading ruthenium, palladium, and rhodium on styrene-DVB cross linked polymer [24–26]. This might be due to the lack of access of ligands to the metal ions. However, anchoring of the metal complex on to the polymer was confirmed by comparative spectral studies of polymer bound complex. The various IR frequencies assigned for N–H, metal–N, and CH2–C(Cl)=C groups are 3438, 532, and 1699 cm−1, respectively. ESR was recorded in the granular form of 3 on ESR, Bruker EMX instrument. The main peak at 3440 G is due to C− radical while other small signals with g value 2 may be due to Mn+ species which indicates that Mn is present in +2 oxidation state. In DTA-TG analysis, it was found that polymer degradation starts above 125°C. A weight loss of about 5% below this temperature may be due to moisture content. Hence, it was ensured that the polymer-anchored catalyst 3 may be used in catalytic studies below 125°C. The surface area of the support 2 was found to be 37.37 m2/g while that of the catalyst 3 is 24.00 m2/g. The decrease in the surface area observed after loading the metal ions on to the polymer support might be due to blocking of pores of the polymer support after introducing the ligand and the metal ions and is in accordance with our previous observations [7,8,26]. Based on the above spectral evidence, the possible picture of the synthesis and structure of the catalyst may be projected as shown in Scheme 1 where polymer-anchored o-phenylene diamine is 2 and its Mn complex is 3. 3.2 Catalytic aziridination of olefins Several methods are reported for the direct aziridination of olefins with a variety of reagents used as source of the nitrogen component [14–18]. Recently, {N-(arenesulfonyl)imino}-phenyliodinanes have been widely used for the aziridination of olefins. However, their preparation is difficult and gives iodobenzene as a byproduct in the reaction. Recently, few groups have reported chloramine-T as an alternative source of nitrogen for this transformation [27–29]. For the first time, we used bromamine-T for this purpose and found it to be superior in this reaction [19]. In the preliminary communication, we have used copper chloride as the catalyst for the reaction. The polymer-anchored Mn-complex 3 was now screened as heterogeneous catalyst for the aziridination of olefins with bromamine-T, 1 as the source of nitrogen. A standard reaction was run with styrene as the test substrate (Eq. 1). The aziridine was isolated in 42% yield after the reaction was left for 15 h at ambient temperature. (1) The catalyst was physically separated and recycled for two more times with very little loss of activity (Table 2) indicating its reusability. A variety of olefins have been successfully examined for this useful transformation and the results are presented in Table 2. Catalytic aziridination of nitrene source with cyclohexene has been a peculiar case due to the formation of undesired insertion products [30–32]. However, in this procedure we have isolated required aziridine of cyclohexene, albeit in moderate yields. This catalyst has worked better than Mn based homogeneous system investigated for {N-(p-tolylsulfonyl)imino}phenyliodinane by Evans et al. [16]. 4 Conclusion We have presented preparation of a new polymer-supported Mn (II) complex with simple synthetic manipulations from commercially available chloromethylated resin. A systematic characterization of this material and catalytic activity for the aziridination of olefins has been carried out. The efficiency of this catalyst for the particular reaction has been established with a wide range of substrates and easy recoverability and reusability of the system. coredata.dc:description: Chloromethylated styrene-divinyl benzene of 8% cross-link was functionalized using o-phenylene diamine and finally it was treated with Mn(II) for the formation of metal complex on the surface. The metal content was estimated using atomic absorption spectroscopy. The thermal stability of the catalyst was seen by the use of DTA-TG analyses and the catalyst was found to be stable up to ~125°C. The modern spectroscopic methods such as FT-IR, ESR were used in order to confirm the probable structure of the catalyst. The catalytic activity of this supported Mn(II)-complex was investigated for aziridination of olefins with bromamine-T as the source of nitrogen. The catalyst was found to be effective in this reaction and could be reused with no substantial loss of activity for up to three cycles.
